bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Roger Brooke, August 14, 1940

div1.p: Hench sends photographs of the Camp Columbia model to Carlisle Barracks, to assist the curator in assembling the model properly for more photographs.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Roger Brooke, August 14, 1940
div1.opener:
August 14, 1940
Brig. General Roger Brooke
The Medical Field Service School
Carlisle Barracks,
Carlisle, Pa.
My dear General Brooke:
div1.p:
May I express my apologies for not having answered your kind letter
of July 5 before this. I wrote you on June 25, asking whether you still had the
model of Camp Columbia, at Havana, made in 1901, and whether I could have a
photograph of this model, looking down on it from the front. You wrote me that
this model was still in storage because no one knew how it should have been put
together. I am sending you herewith the two photographs of this model which I
obtained from the Army Medical Museum. These will show how the model apparently
should be set up. If you care to keep these two photographs, you may do so,
but if you can obtain copies from the Medical Museum, I shall appreciate the
return of my two photographs. I shall be glad to pay for the photographs
taken from the front of this model.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
